t1-64-lag-clet-spine.j2 is missing?
The file is a symbol link. Please ignore.

Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

@wangxin I tried using testbed-cli.sh announce_route functionality, but in the 'inventory' field in the testbed.csv, if I give 'lab' as the inventory name, then we get error as it can't find host corresponding to 'server_1' in the inventory.

```
/data/ansible$
/data/ansible$ cat testbed.csv | grep ^chassis2-t2
chassis2-t2,vms_2,t2,docker-ptf,ptf_vms_12,10.250.0.188/24,,server_12,VM0100,[board7;board4;board3;sup2],lab,False,T2 OC Tests chassis2

/data/ansible$ ./testbed-cli.sh -t testbed.csv -m veos announce-routes chassis2-t2 password.txt
Announce routes 'chassis2-t2'
reading
/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ansible/parsing/vault/__init__.py:44: CryptographyDeprecationWarning: Python 2 is no longer supported by the Python core team. Support for it is now deprecated in cryptography, and will be removed in a future release.
  from cryptography.exceptions import InvalidSignature
[WARNING]: Could not match supplied host pattern, ignoring: server_1

ERROR! Specified hosts and/or --limit does not match any hosts
/data/ansible$ 

```
In order for it to work, I had to give 'veos' as the inventory name. But this is already being passed with '-m option'. So, why are we dependent on inv_name for announce_route.

So a quick comment on these tests, the cases involving active ToR BGP shutdown are actually expected to fail/not switchover since this functionality was not implemented. I believe it was up for discussion when I first wrote the test plan, but we decided not to implement it.

At this point, I am letting the testcase be there and fail (as expected).

Thanks for catching and fixing!
@lolyu can you elaborate more why there would be 2 pytest clients trying to connection ptf nn at the same time?
/AZP run

> @lolyu can you elaborate more why there would be 2 pytest clients trying to connection ptf nn at the same time?

It usually happened when we were debugging test cases, but left the debug session alive after we finished, or when the terminal was closed unexpectedly. At such cases, the connection between ```ptf_nn_agent```  and ```ptf_adapter``` will be keep permanently unless we kill the ```ptf_adapter``` process. If Jenkins jobs starts at the same time, or other users begin debugging, there would be more than one TCP client that are attempting to establish a connection to ```ptf_nn_agent```. The later connection will fail.

comments.body:
> @stephenxs, can you raise your concern on the LAG ports being added for testing?

Hi 
sure.
One of the steps in QoS test is to close the egress port in order to create congestion. For LAG member ports, this prevents the LACP packets from being sent. The LACP protocol needs to send BPDU to swap information between the peers and keep the LAG ports connected. It can tolerate 3 BPDU packets lost at maximum, which is 90 seconds (3*30). However, for some of the QoS test cases, eg. the watermark or shared headroom pool cases, it can take more than 90 seconds because 
 - it needs to send the sufficient amount of packets to occupy the shared buffer, which takes a lot of time 
 - there are a lot of delays during the test in order to make sure the counters updated 

This can cause the LAG port down. One it’s down, there will be other unexpected behaviors.

> > @stephenxs, can you raise your concern on the LAG ports being added for testing?
> 
> Hi
> sure.
> One of the steps in QoS test is to close the egress port in order to create congestion. For LAG member ports, this prevents the LACP packets from being sent. The LACP protocol needs to send BPDU to swap information between the peers and keep the LAG ports connected. It can tolerate 3 BPDU packets lost at maximum, which is 90 seconds (3*30). However, for some of the QoS test cases, eg. the watermark or shared headroom pool cases, it can take more than 90 seconds because
> 
> * it needs to send the sufficient amount of packets to occupy the shared buffer, which takes a lot of time
> * there are a lot of delays during the test in order to make sure the counters updated
> 
> This can cause the LAG port down. One it’s down, there will be other unexpected behaviors.

90 secs is a lot of time to fill the queue. What's the size of the queue (or buffer)? Will increasing the packet size help? I haven't found a way to increase tiemout by more than 90 sec. Since the topology has two member ports, changing the min_links to 1 will prevent from bringing down the interface. But would like to explore other options.

> 
> 90 secs is a lot of time to fill the queue. What's the size of the queue (or buffer)? Will increasing the packet size help? I haven't found a way to increase tiemout by more than 90 sec. Since the topology has two member ports, changing the min_links to 1 will prevent from bringing down the interface. But would like to explore other options.

I just checked the results on one testbed of ours. The PGsharedWatermark is the most time-consuming test among four test cases. ~105 seconds. It needs to send ~70000 packets to occupy the shared buffer. If the `pkts_num_trig_pfc` or `pkts_num_trig_egr_drp` aren't that big, I think it's unlikely to hit that limit.
BTW, just FYI, If I'm not mistaken, the 90 seconds limit is a hard limit for LACP defined in IEEE 802.
Also to change min_links won't help because once the LACP expired the physical member will be removed from the LAG in the ASIC and the traffic will be re-hashed to another lag member.

> > 90 secs is a lot of time to fill the queue. What's the size of the queue (or buffer)? Will increasing the packet size help? I haven't found a way to increase tiemout by more than 90 sec. Since the topology has two member ports, changing the min_links to 1 will prevent from bringing down the interface. But would like to explore other options.
> 
> I just checked the results on one testbed of ours. The PGsharedWatermark is the most time-consuming test among four test cases. ~105 seconds. It needs to send ~70000 packets to occupy the shared buffer. If the `pkts_num_trig_pfc` or `pkts_num_trig_egr_drp` aren't that big, I think it's unlikely to hit that limit.
> BTW, just FYI, If I'm not mistaken, the 90 seconds limit is a hard limit for LACP defined in IEEE 802.
> Also to change min_links won't help because once the LACP expired the physical member will be removed from the LAG in the ASIC and the traffic will be re-hashed to another lag member.

Thanks for checking. You are right about LACP, so that's not an option. I tried the test on Broadcom ASIC and so far it hasn't failed. As long as the test gives good signal I suggest we run it. This test will not run on Mellanox as the LAG ports are removed. If there is flakiness the PGsharedWatermark can be disabled (in the test script) if there are only LAG ports. Ability to do tx disable at queue level would have been good.

The change is good. I was wondering if it's possible that we can miss some import not updated? I did a search for ```tests.common.devices```, and seems all cases are updated.

Updated the PR with another way of committing the changes. Most git blame history can be preserved. In case you need to get a more accurate git blame history, please try command `git blame -C <filename>`.

@sujinmkang  can you update how you verified it?

The reboot test so far has assumption that the reboot command is available on target device, so it didn't check if the command exists or not before executing it. Can you add a check? Otherwise, this test will fail on many branches until the cherry-pick is done.
